sub_topic: The butterfly effect and its implications in chaotic systems
message_1: Suppose that a chaotic system is described by the equation x<sub>n+1</sub> = r sin(πx<sub>n</sub>) for n = 0, 1, 2, ..., where r is a constant parameter and x<sub>0</sub> is the initial value of x. If r = 3.6 and x<sub>0</sub> = 0.5, determine the next three values of x (i.e., x<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>3</sub>).
message_2:
Given the equation x<sub>n+1</sub> = r sin(πx<sub>n</sub>), r = 3.6, and x<sub>0</sub> = 0.5, we can find the next three values of x as follows:

1. Calculate x<sub>1</sub>:
x<sub>1</sub> = 3.6 * sin(π * 0.5)
x<sub>1</sub> = 3.6 * sin(π/2)
x<sub>1</sub> = 3.6 * 1
x<sub>1</sub> = 3.6

2. Calculate x<sub>2</sub>:
x<sub>2</sub> = 3.6 * sin(π * 3.6)
x<sub>2</sub> ≈ 3.6 * sin(11.30973355)
x<sub>2</sub> ≈ 3.6 * (-0.997205)
x<sub>2</sub> ≈ -3.589938

3. Calculate x<sub>3</sub>:
x<sub>3</sub> = 3.6 * sin(π * (-3.589938))
x<sub>3</sub> ≈ 3.6 * sin(-11.289371)
x<sub>3</sub> ≈ 3.6 * 0.998587
x<sub>3</sub> ≈ 3.594513

So, the next three values of x are x<sub>1</sub> = 3.6, x<sub>2</sub> ≈ -3.589938, and x<sub>3</sub> ≈ 3.594513.
